summary: (Because I creep on the tags) your take on Crowley and Aziraphale is so hot it's solar
question: (Because I creep on the tags) your take on Crowley and Aziraphale is so hot it's solar
answer:
is this the one about crowley having been in love with azira so long he’s just so annoyed by now and aziraphale only coming to terms with his feelings now so he’s struggling to hide them?

because like, let me tell you, i totally dig this dynamic– i love the book dynamic and i adore it when crowley is a anxious little serpent that can’t get a hold of his fickle feelings and aziraphale being a little grumpy but totally calm that he has somehow fallen for the enemy whilst trying to rationalize it.

but the idea of aziraphale slowly realizing that he’s in too deep and using the “but you’re a demon therefore ______” more and more as an act of self-defense? ugh. yes. YES. and crowley getting really tired of making all of this love evident to his stubborn angel? and just overall really annoyed that he still can’t not love this utterly daft divine fool? ugh. yES.

the whole “would i lie to you” in the trailer is just such a desperate plea to be seen, for feelings to be returned. and azira just brushes it off because accepting his feelings means accepting that somewhere along the way he’s done something “wrong” and that he’s not as perfectly good as he thinks himself to be.

and that breaks my heart just as much as it mends it.

title: Good Omens: A Concept
body:
The show is over, or nearly over. Some people think it’s great, best adaptation to ever be made, perfectly in keeping with the book. Other people think it’s awful: horrendous! An insult to the authors, even if one of them had a hand in making it. Either way, we are wrapping up. Anathema has received the second book of prophecies (to be immediately thrown out). Adam has run off to see the circus with Dog. And Crowley and Aziraphale, well that’s the major sticking point among the fans.

Any and all inference that these two characters were in a relationship (romantic or otherwise) seemed to be completely erased. Sure, Tennant and Sheen played them as characters who were in love with one another. There were sidelong glances and loving stares. But once you remove the actors’ interpretations, you’re left with a show in which an angel and a demon were very good colleagues. They didn’t even hold hands at the climax!

If there was anything the fans of the book could agree upon, it would be how utterly terrible the relationship between these two man-shaped entities was developed in the show. Still, they are sticking it out to the end.

The final scene comes up. Crowley and Aziraphale are at the Ritz. This scene was in the trailers so the audience knows how it’s going to end. Some people minimize the window, looking for something else to watch. Others pull up their phone, scrolling through Twitter or Tumblr to see if they’re going to have to disagree with some people.

“To the world,” Crowley says.

We all know how this is going to end.

Aziraphale pauses and Michael Sheen puts the most adoring look on his face. “To the world.”

The camera starts to pull out as they clink their glasses, revealing more and more of the dining room. Some people have already clicked off the video, not wanting to watch the credits. Others have gotten up, thoroughly disappointed with the lack of clear LGBTQ+ subtext that was so present in the novel. A few watch on.

The camera pauses so that Crowley and Aziraphale are sitting far in the background. The dishes on the table go flying! Crashing to the ground. Both man-shaped entities grapple at each other, making out furiously as they roll off the table and onto the floor, leaving destruction in their wake.

The screen cuts to black. It was only a second.

The fans that are still left stare open-mouthed at the screen. Did I really just see that? They take to social media.

The viewers who checked out early think it’s another joke. There’s no way that happened. It takes them weeks to realize the truth.

Someplace far away, the directors, writers, actors, and producers are all laughing. They just reverse-queer-baited the entire audience. The natural order of things has been restored.

summary:
Aziraphale/Crowley - You’re No Saint 
You're standing here like an angry guy Counting all my sins just to cross them off Saying...
caption:
Aziraphale/Crowley - You’re No Saint

You’re standing here like an angry guy
Counting all my sins just to cross them off
Saying in my tongue, we still lie to trust
And in my blood couldn’t keep you

My dear, you’re not so innocent
You’re fooling Heaven’s gates
So you won’t have to change
You’re no saint, you’re no saint, yeah

summary: ☀️Aziraphale and Crowley go to the beach for some reason, on a rare occasion when the British weather is actually not that bad...
question: ☀️Aziraphale and Crowley go to the beach for some reason, on a rare occasion when the British weather is actually not that bad (inspired imaginatively by the prompt emoji ☀️) I imagine neither would enjoy the sand and sea that much, but you may disagree! Thanks
answer:
My Ask | My Ko-Fi | My Ao3 | Requests always welcome!

Put a ☀️ and a prompt in my ask for a minifill!

Aziraphale leaned over, swiping one of Crowley’s chips from in front of him, and Crowley smiled at him affectionately, his chin rested on his hand. Aziraphale looking at him for a long moment, his brow furrowing slightly.

“What?”

“You don’t think it’s a bit silly,” Crowley asked, “that we’re here at the beach, and we’re sitting on the promenade, eating fish and chips, and not going on the beach, or in the sea?”

Aziraphale looked horrified. “Why? Do you want to go on the beach?”

“No.”

“Do you want to go in the water?”

“I wouldn’t mind a swim.”

“In that body?”

“Maybe not.”

“Well, then! Honestly, dear boy, I don’t think it’s that odd. We’re here for the sunshine, and the– You know, the mood of it. And you want to go into the amusement arcade, don’t you?”

“Of course I do,” Crowley said. “I invented half those machines.” Crowley reached over, taking hold of Aziraphale’s hand, and he drew Aziraphale’s plump fingers up to his mouth, dragging his mouth over the soft knuckles. “I’m just saying, angel. It’s a seaside rendezvous. We should… enjoy the seaside a little bit.”

“I’m enjoying it,” Aziraphale murmured, squeezing Crowley’s fingers. “And I don’t want to take off my shoes.”

Crowley smiled, and kissed his knuckles once again.

blog.name: crowleydear
blog.title: To the w o r l d
blog.description: Kieran/Ciarán / he/him / world's best whatever / Tolkien blog is @bifaramir

body:
Twin constants–an early summer’s evening

So I was talking to @not-so-good-omens and a ficlet happened… And I was encouraged to post it… So here it is, unedited gjskgkd! Hope it isn’t too terrible–have Aziraphale and Crowley sitting in a sand dune on the beach where I grew up

Aziraphale leaned onto the trunk of the wizened pine tree and dug a hand into the sand on top of the dune. Crowley watched the back of his head, curls seeming to be set on fire in the glow of the setting sun, reminiscent of the halo which had rested above them long ago, and sighed softly as the angel leaned into him. He wrapped an arm around him and listened to the sea rushing in, and was slowly drawn into that deep reflective contemplation which offered neither escape nor respite.

It had been six thousand years. Six thousand years of knowing each other and talking to each other and sharing drinks and food and then more drinks and sometimes more food after that. He’d heard every one of the angel’s spontaneous, idiosyncratic little thoughts, familiarized himself with every one of his habits and memorized every line in his face, and yet every day he spent with Aziraphale was another day he was happy to have known. Alone, he was in his element. He was cool, he was suave, he was always on top of everything. With Aziraphale, he was thrown off guard every other minute, he was tumbling through the strange feeling of perhaps, just maybe, not being the smartest person in the room, nor the most loved. He was whole, with the angel. He knew himself, and then he knew himself-with-Aziraphale. With the angel, he voiced doubts,admittedly through a thick veneer of faked cynical apathy, and was returned them twofold.

He could stay here forever with the angel under his arm, was complete with the angel, and could never have lived without him. Someone, had he really just thought that? Could he not live without Aziraphale? Maybe he couldn’t. Maybe not. He could surely see himself living with the angel forever… In their little lives while the world changed, with Aziraphale’s books and Crowley’s cool car and them, the twin constants of the human world throughout six millennia. He would set the world on fire for Aziraphale, he knew. But greater still than that, he would save the world for him. He already had, in a way. He loved humanity, loved the world, but always Aziraphale had brought it to light, in evenings spent in London bars getting drunk with Shakespeare, days in medieval Constantinople eating fruit on plush divans, sunrises in Ur where Aziraphale pointed out the shape of the ziggurats, said he’d been very proud of those, and Crowley remembered the commendation for future archeological bafflement he’d gotten. He would die for his angel, and now, he thought, he was living for his angel.

Always it had been this way, and always it would remain this way, and now the thought struck Crowley that, this way that he’d loved Aziraphale, had always been returned to him. That the warmth of Aziraphale’s smiles and the gentleness of his touch and the lilt of his laugh had led him along the same path at whose end, at the edge of the yellow wood of loving and living and knowing, Crowley now found himself. And Crowley allowed himself to sink into the comfortable warmth of the angel beneath him, and pressed a kiss into his curls, and was content to find that the kiss was returned into the crook of his neck as he saw the water shimmer beyond them, the last light of the sun disappearing to let the stars take its place, and the breeze being ever so slightly too cool for anyone not wrapped in the arms of another

summary: 🌞 ahh a/c, public sex, top crowley?
question: 🌞 ahh a/c, public sex, top crowley?
answer:
My Ask | My Ko-Fi | My Ao3 | Requests always welcome!

Put a ☀️ and a prompt in my ask for a minifill!

Crowley has been, mostly at Aziraphale’s behest, to at least a thousand poetry readings in his lifetime. Probably more than that, actually. Thousands and thousands of them. And he isn’t opposed to poetry! Poetry is fine. Sometimes, it’s even good. He and the angel tend to differ on what exactly is good, but that’s fine, that’s just fine.

And tonight–

Well.

Tonight is different. 

It’s a year after the almost-apocalypse. It’s a year and a half since they last went to a poetry reading. And right now? Aziraphale is squirming in his seat, and Crowley is fascinated. 

His chin is rested against his palm, his fingers against his lips, and he watches Aziraphale, whose gaze is fixated on the young man on the stage, who is reading from, of all people, Ginsberg. He and Aziraphale have fought about Ginsberg for a little under forty years: ordinarily, Aziraphale (and Crowley, too, although he’d be much more ready to admit to it) has a habit of taking outsiders into his heart, and always has a deep affection for poets… He’d sobbed over Oscar Wilde, after the trial and after he’d died, but Ginsberg has never appealed to him.

He’s obscene, Crowley.

Yes, angel, that’s what the trial’s for. 

Oh, the trial! Ridiculous! He oughtn’t be on trial, obviously, but I just say from a place of personal preference that I really– No, I just don’t see all that focus on…

Sex?

Yes! Sex! It’s excessive!

But now…?

Aziraphale’s cheeks are burning with red heat, his eyes wide, and he has one of his plump, lovely palms pressed tight against his mouth, his finger and thumb gripping tightly enough at his own jaw that Crowley can see the flesh dimple. 

His legs are crossed. Tightly.

Crowley grins. 

“Angel,” he says, when the lad finishes, and Aziraphale turns to look at him, his eyes widening a little more.

“Hm?” he asks, like he’s frightened to actually open his mouth to talk. 

Crowley stands, and he gestures for Aziraphale to follow him, which he hesitates before so doing: their fingers interlink as Crowley leads Aziraphale by his hand out of the bar. It makes sense, of course, that some poetry is in a slightly different perspective now. He and Aziraphale have embarked on a few new journeys in the past year, and sex is part of it, sex is a big part of it–

“Oh, dear boy, what are we doing?” Aziraphale asks as Crowley drags him into the little supplies cupboard, and Crowley pulls him up into a hard kiss, and Aziraphale gasps into his mouth, shuddering and leaning up against Crowley’s body. He is all but trembling, and Crowley grabs at his arse through the grey fabric of his trousers, and Aziraphale lets out a heady noise against Crowley’s mouth.

“Bend over,” Crowley says.

“Crowley, we can’t, what if someone–”

“You just got hot and bothered at a poetry reading, angel: bend over.”

Crowley doesn’t wait for him to argue: he manhandles Aziraphale and shoves him up against one of the shelves, ignoring the clink of bottles against one another, and Aziraphale heaves in a gasp, but he doesn’t complain. 

“You get it now, huh, angel?” Crowley hisses in his ear, and he bites at the back of his neck, feeling Aziraphale’s legs spread apart before his knees even as he whimpers. “I remember, I read you Please Master, and you just stared at me the whole time, all blank-faced and snooty, and now–”

“Oh, no, no, Crowley, you mustn’t–”

“Please master can I touch your cheek / Please master can I kneel at your feet–”

“Oh, Crowley, I’m too weak for poetry right now, I, oh–”

Crowley laughs against the back of his neck, his tongue flickering out and catching at his earlobe, and Aziraphale heaves in a noise as Crowley gets his hand down the back of his trousers, dipping between his arsecheeks and delighting in the wail Aziraphale lets out. 

“Someone’s going to hear us, Crowley–”

“Oh, no, no, darling,” Crowley purrs, “they’ll only hear you.” Aziraphale moans as Crowley twists his wrist, his thighs falling open as he leans heavily on the shelves. “Please master can I loosen your blue pants–”

“Oh, Crowley, don’t tease me,” Aziraphale begs, and Crowley drags hard at his trousers, pulling them down along with Aziraphale’s stupid, old-fashioned breeches, and then he drops to his knees. 

Aziraphale is lucky Crowley thought to soundproof the little room as he’d entered, because with this noise, he certainly would have forgotten if he’d left it in any later.

And he isn’t opposed to poetry! Poetry is fine. Sometimes, it’s even good. He and the angel tend to differ on what exactly is good, but that’s fine, that’s just fine.

And tonight–

Well.

Tonight is different. 

It’s a year after the almost-apocalypse. It’s a year and a half since they last went to a poetry reading. And right now? Aziraphale is squirming in his seat, and Crowley is fascinated. 

His chin is rested against his palm, his fingers against his lips, and he watches Aziraphale, whose gaze is fixated on the young man on the stage, who is reading from, of all people, Ginsberg. He and Aziraphale have fought about Ginsberg for a little under forty years: ordinarily, Aziraphale (and Crowley, too, although he’d be much more ready to admit to it) has a habit of taking outsiders into his heart, and always has a deep affection for poets… He’d sobbed over Oscar Wilde, after the trial and after he’d died, but Ginsberg has never appealed to him.

He’s obscene, Crowley.

Yes, angel, that’s what the trial’s for. 

Oh, the trial! Ridiculous! He oughtn’t be on trial, obviously, but I just say from a place of personal preference that I really– No, I just don’t see all that focus on…

Sex?

Yes! Sex! It’s excessive!

But now…?

Aziraphale’s cheeks are burning with red heat, his eyes wide, and he has one of his plump, lovely palms pressed tight against his mouth, his finger and thumb gripping tightly enough at his own jaw that Crowley can see the flesh dimple. 

His legs are crossed. Tightly.

Crowley grins. 

“Angel,” he says, when the lad finishes, and Aziraphale turns to look at him, his eyes widening a little more.

“Hm?” he asks, like he’s frightened to actually open his mouth to talk.

He is all but trembling, and Crowley grabs at his arse through the grey fabric of his trousers, and Aziraphale lets out a heady noise against Crowley’s mouth.

“Bend over,” Crowley says.

“Crowley, we can’t, what if someone–”

“You just got hot and bothered at a poetry reading, angel: bend over.”

Crowley doesn’t wait for him to argue: he manhandles Aziraphale and shoves him up against one of the shelves, ignoring the clink of bottles against one another, and Aziraphale heaves in a gasp, but he doesn’t complain.

“Oh, no, no, Crowley, you mustn’t–”

“Oh, Crowley, I’m too weak for poetry right now, I, oh–”

title: has anyone else noticed this??
body:
this

is NOT the same scene as this!!

they are cut like they’re playing right after one another but the differences are frankly glaring!! the darker wall, the window, the figure pinning Aziraphale looking preeeetty female and definitely not like Crowley

am i wrong?? and if not… what is going on here with our favorite angel + getting pinned against walls??? XD
